comment.author: 83979593@N00
comment._content:
The captions, annotations, and technical notes for the Goodyear images were transcribed from Goodyear's own descriptive text; variation in spellings for city and site names in these descriptions reflect his usage. When necessary, staff created captions or augmented Goodyear's text. Country, city and site names in the headings have been regularized. The spelling may be the form at the time as seen in this NY Times article from Oct. 7, 1896.

query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9A 0DEEDD133BEE...

We’ll add the recommended spelling to our catalog record. Thanks!

comment.author: 8069016@N07
comment._content: It's Iéna with an i, not an L, by the way. (Unless yours is a more arcane spelling?) Not sure if it helps, but there is an old postcard of Trocadéro and Pont d'Iéna on Wikimedia: commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Image:75-Paris-Trocad%c3%a9ro_... Also, I was wondering if this is definitely an aerial view-- it seems low. If a blimp were in that exact positioning for the photograph, I'm pretty sure it would have run into the Eiffel Tower...

comment.author: 7353175@N04
comment._content:
Of course this is a view from the first or second floor of the Eiffel tower. This is in 1900 and the tower was constructed in 1889. Iéna is the french translation of Jena, which is the original german name of the city nearby Napoleon's battle againt Prussia. As "J" is pronounced "I" in german, it is written "I" in french. 

The twin battles of Jena and Auerstedt (older name: Auerstädt) were fought on 14 October 1806 on the plateau west of the river Saale in today's Germany, between the forces of Napoleon I of France and Frederick William III of Prussia. The decisive defeat suffered by the Prussian army a mere nineteen days after its mobilization resulted in Prussia's elimination from the fourth anti-French coalition until the liberation war of 1813. (Wikipedia)
